item.title: Goldman Sachs Opens Biggest Office Outside New York in Mumbai
item.description: Goldman Sachs Opens Biggest Office Outside New York in Mumbai Goldman Sachs has opened its biggest office outside of New York City in Mumbai, India. The new office will employ 6,000 people and focus on areas such as investment banking, asset management, and securities services.

item.title: India's Inflation to Cool Gradually, Central Bank Chief Says
item.description: India’s Inflation to Cool Gradually India’s inflation is expected to cool gradually from October, Reserve Bank of India Governor Shaktikanta Das said. The central bank has raised interest rates by 90 basis points in the last two months in an attempt to control inflation.

item.title: Sizzling Rally in Indian Property Stocks Seen Extending on Rates
item.description: Rally in Indian Property Stocks Seen Extending on Rates Indian property stocks have rallied sharply in recent months, with the NSE Nifty Realty Index gaining more than 36% since March lows. The rally has been driven by a number of factors, including expectations that the central bank may start cutting interest rates next year.

item.title: Supply Chain Latest: India Decoupling From China
item.description: India Decouples From China India is increasingly decoupling from China in terms of its supply chains. This is due to a number of factors, including the ongoing trade war between the United States and China, as well as India’s own economic growth and ambitions.

item.title: India: Vedanta Chip Setback Shows Cracks in Modi's Economic Push
item.description: Modi’s Economic Push Hits a Major Setback The Indian government’s $24 billion plan to boost manufacturing in the country has hit a major setback, with Vedanta Resources Ltd.’s $10 billion chip unit being delayed. The delay is a blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s efforts to make India a global manufacturing hub and comes at a time when the country’s economy is facing headwinds from rising inflation and a slowdown in growth.

item.title: Russia's Rupee Trap Is Adding to $147 Billion Hoard Stuck Abroad
item.description: Russia’s Rupee Trap Russia has been selling oil to India in exchange for rupees, but it has been difficult for Russia to use these rupees to buy goods and services from India. This is because India has strict foreign exchange controls that make it difficult for foreigners to repatriate rupees.
